<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: public class TestStringTokenStrict {
```arduino
/**
 * Strict implementation of StringTokenizer
 * 
 * @param str
 * @param delim
 *            true = include NULL Token
 * @return
 */
static StringTokenizer getStringTokenizerStrict(String str, String delim, boolean strict) {
    StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(str, delim, strict);
    StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();

    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String s = st.nextToken();
        if (s.equals(delim)) {
            sb.append(" ").append(delim);
        } else {
            sb.append(s).append(delim);
            if (st.hasMoreTokens())
                st.nextToken();
        }
    }
    return (new StringTokenizer(sb.toString(), delim));
}

static void altStringTokenizer(StringTokenizer st) {
    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String type = st.nextToken();
        String one = st.nextToken();
        String two = st.nextToken();
        String three = st.nextToken();
        String four = st.nextToken();
        String five = st.nextToken();

        System.out.println(
                "[" + type + "] [" + one + "] [" + two + "] [" + three + "] [" + four + "] [" + five + "]");
    }
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
    String input = "Record|One||Three||Five";
    altStringTokenizer(getStringTokenizerStrict(input, "|", true));
}
```
}

In this code, the `getStringTokenizerStrict` method creates a strict implementation of the `StringTokenizer` class that includes NULL tokens in the output. The `altStringTokenizer` method then uses this implementation to tokenize the input string and print out the results.

To use this code to split a string with tabs as delimiters, you would need to modify the `getStringTokenizerStrict` method to use tabs as the delimiter instead of spaces. You could do this by replacing the `StringTokenizer` constructor call with a call to `new StringTokenizer(str, "\t", strict)`. This would create a `StringTokenizer` object that uses tabs as delimiters and includes NULL tokens in the output.

Alternatively, you could modify the `altStringTokenizer` method to handle tabs as delimiters by replacing the `StringTokenizer` constructor call with a call to `new StringTokenizer(str, "\t", false)`. This would create a `StringTokenizer` object that uses tabs as delimiters but does not include NULL tokens in the output. You could then modify the loop that processes the tokens to handle tabs appropriately.
